comments.text:
+Suited Socialist
I'm not going to state my opinions on anything because I don't feel like 
getting in an argument with anyone, but I can agree on some points there. I 
never, ever give Wikipedia as a source. Because it's true that it can be 
changed. The only point I was really trying to make was that it's easy to 
find out if the wiki is accurate at all by going to the sources at the 
bottom and reading through them. I HAVE found Wikipedia as a very useful 
place to start, by pulling up a topic, and then going down to the sources. 
It's a easy place to find sources specifically for the topic your looking 
for instead of going through university library pages and the likes (though 
those can be extremely useful, depending).

I'm not saying anyone should give Wikipedia as a source (though in my 
studies and discussions with professors, I've found that the majority of 
wiki tends to be accurate, because even though anyone can change it to 
something wrong, that wrong information rarely stays there. Though I can 
agree that it's very likely that political groups, ideas, and myths would 
be glaringly inaccurate.). However, again, it is easy to prove or disprove 
a wiki by going to it's sources. I always go down to the sources first, and 
if there are none, I won't even bother to look at the rest of the page. If 
there are, I may read through the wiki page to give me a basic summary, 
then go to the sources to both confirm and inform more in depth. Wiki can 
be good for quickly finding what part of something you want to be looking 
at, and then you can go and find good sources on that specific thing.

Once again, I don't source Wikipedia pages. If someone else does, I can 
either go through the sources to see if the page is accurate. If it's not, 
instead of saying "Wikipedia isn't a valid source", I'll simply rebuttal 
with an actual reliable source, and THEN I might mention something along 
the lines (shorter) of what I've just gone over. Wikipedia can be a helpful 
place to start, but it is not completely reliable as it CAN be changed, so 
if you want solid ground to stand on, cite something better. Wikipedia is 
more of a list of possible sources to go through than anything else.

+Eleftherios II † No true scotsman fallacy. You don't get to choose who is 
and isn't a christian. None of the things you've said have anything to do 
with if someone is a christian or not.

Since I know you're not gonna bother looking up what a no true scotsman is, 
here, "No True Scotsman is a logical fallacy by which an individual 
attempts to avoid being associated with an unpleasant act by asserting that 
no true member of the group they belong to would do such a thing; this 
fallacy also applies to defining a term or criteria biasedly as to defend 
it from counterargument which can be identified as a biased, persuasive, or 
rhetorical definition. Instead of acknowledging that some members of a 
group have undesirable characteristics, the fallacy tries to redefine the 
group to exclude them. Sentences such as "all members of X have desirable 
trait Y" then become tautologies, because Y becomes a requirement of 
membership in X.
The fallacy does not occur in defining a group or label narrowly to begin 
with, but in narrowing it by excluding evidence that contradicts an 
initially broad definition."

comments.text:
As for Big Bang having evidence, might I ask a simple question? Where did 
the dot come from. The official answer thus far, from multiple scientists I 
have asked, is that they simply don't know. Understandibly, they were 
neither there at the time nor have found a way to research that far. 
Similarly, Evolution has multiple 'plotholes' as well. Logically speaking, 
if human evolved from apes, and we still have both humans AND apes, there 
would be at the very least a handful of races that are identifiably in 
between. Similarly, there would be a far greater number of animals out 
there that seem to be in between evolutionary links for every other species 
as well, such as Dogs and Direwolves. Further complications occur in that 
the First cell had to of been created. Granted that a single cell would be 
needed to reproduce, and granted that the earth is billions of years old 
(more likely, but also debatable), it is possible evolution could have 
occured. A single cell, however, is complicated enough that a HUGE number 
of processes go into its creation. Here is some evidence -   
http://www.windows2universe.org/earth/Life/cell_mitosis.html
With this in mind, for such to of occured without involvement from a 
sentient organism is almost certainly impossible. So, aliens or god. Your 
choice.
   That, of course, is not to mention that certain adaptions, such as a 
Giraffe having an extremely powerful heart able to raise and lower blood 
pressure as well as a neck able to reach the tops of trees, (since it needs 
high pressure to reach its head when leaning up, and the amount of pressure 
used could theoretically BLOW ITS HEAD OFF if it leans down), would be 
useless without the addition of the other said adaptation.
     Finally, despite both them AND the bible having plotholes, I must ask 
a simple question: Does the Bible contradict Big Bang Theory OR the theory 
of Evolution? Even if they are true (a fact I am skepctical of), the bible 
doesn't describe how mankind was made. Therefore, even if said theories are 
correct, it does not disprove the Bible.
   Sorry if you take offense to reading this, but ultimately it is my 
belief. You believe in your books, I believe in mine. Personally, I fully 
support any religion, including Big Bang and Evolution. I only get 
defensive when people say things like "I am glad those idiots are dead".

however, is what's delusional. Parting the Red Sea and walking on water are 
things no sane individual with any knowledge of physics at all believes 
happened. I'm not saying that Noah's Ark didn't exist, as it's believed to 
have been discovered in petrified form. The existence of Jesus was 
confirmed as well, though it's been long enough since reading up on the 
confirmation that I forget the details of how. The reason I trust science 
is that they label things as what they are. If you notice, there are very 
few things that are specifically labeled as scientific laws. Inertia, 
gravity, basically anything in physics. Why I trust science over religion 
is that science has checks and balances in place such as double-blind 
testing to ensure that no bias in the results creeps in and no evidence can 
be tampered with. Scientists pursue the truth - nothing more, nothing less. 
Whereas with religion, you have all kinds of known tampering with the 
accounts of what happened. That's why religion has so many subdivisions. 
Catholics being the most noted for tampering with these texts. And there 
really isn't any system in place to keep this from happening. I think 
that's the reason why so much of the text has become so far-fetched.
comments.author: Paul Lander

again and again that the likelihood that some kind of all-powerful god 
figure is slim to none at best. When people are facing death in such a way 
as people are on death row, rational thought is the last thing going 
through their minds. Desperation, however, is most definitely something 
that's going through their minds. And when you are aware that you are going 
to die for certain, you hope against hope that there is some form of 
salvation. While I would like to believe that there is such a thing as much 
as anyone else, I'm a realist - not some whacko case dreamer who believes 
that the bible is in any way anything less laughable than Greek Mythology. 
Or, for that matter, a blatant work of fiction created by people whose 
curiosity exceeded the equipment they had to indulge their curiosity. 
Modern science has proven that most of the events that took place in the 
bible are either entirely impossible, or that those that did actually take 
place happened in much different ways from what is depicted in the 
supposedly sacred text. In short, just because some desperate psycho killer 
cries out to god before he gets nailed with the electric chair, that 
doesn't mean that the whole religion thing holds any water. What you said 
makes a great line for a movie, but in the real world, we have scientific 
facts that make religion an irrelevant cult.

comments.text:
Actually, the FBI began the events at Waco by attempting to serve warrants, 
the ATF raid started after a fire fight between the FBI and the 
Davidians. The tear gas canisters were fired at a concrete bunker hours 
before the fire broke out. Most of the tear gas was pumped in via tanks. 
There's also tapes from listening devices within the compound that recorded 
members starting fires. The physical evidence also showed that 2 of the 
fires started deep within the compound away from where any tear gas 
entered. David Koresh was a child molesting cult leader who needed to be 
stopped, however it seems like the ATF was too heavy-handed during their 
siege and should've made more attempts to negotiate with the members. Based 
on the physical evidence I don't think the ATF caused the fire, I'm not 
sure if the Davidians intended to kill themselves but it does appear that 
they started the fire that ultimately killed them.

captions.text:
• From cults that'll make you drink some
really bad Kool-Aid to war victims that choose

death over torture, we count 15 times a large
group of people have committed mass suicide

15 - Town of Demmin,
• This took place near the end of World

War 2, almost 1000 people, mostly women and
children that decided to take their own life

instead of getting raped and murdered by the
Soviet Red Army

• It was 1945 when people used everything
from guns to razor blades and poison, slaughtering

their own children and loved ones instead
of enduring the pain and humiliation from

a notorious army
• Sadly, some parents killed their own children

but couldn't die themselves because they didn't
have enough poison leftover to finish the

job
14 - People's Temple,

• 900 members of the infamous religious
group People's Temple that ended their own

lives by consuming a poisonous drink, with
almost 300 of said members being children

forced to commit suicide
• 1978, the goal was to escape fascism by

ending their own lives, defectors who tried
to escape were shot to death as they ran,

and children were injected with the drink
against their will and murdered

• Before this, their members had been encouraged
to drink non-poisonous drink under the belief

it WOULD kill them, but sadly, this time it
really did

13 - Badung,
• A town in Bali attacked by the Dutch army

during 1906, in which the Balinese officials
recognised they'd stand no chance against

the campaign and thus opted to take their
own lives

• They did this by performing the Puputan,
translated into English as simply "The End",

stabbing members of their own family in violent
bloodbaths as if in a trance

• What the Dutch army saw when they arrived
was a horrorshow, dismembered human flesh

everywhere, babies torn to pieces by their
own mothers, so bad that it actually traumatised

these hardened soldiers for a long time afterward
12 - Masada,

• 60AD, Isreal, the Roman conquest of Judea,
over 900 jews barricaded themselves into a

fortress in the Judean Desert and for 12 years
they survived there

• Emperor Lucius Flavius Silvius then constructed
a giant ramp to breach the walls, but by the

time this happened all he and his soldiers
found were burnt buildings and hundreds of

bodies
• Only a handful of survivors lived to tell

the tale, that their leader wanted themselves
slain before wives could be abused and children

sold as slaves
11 - Heaven's Gate,

• 39 followers of this strange religion
in California, 1997, in which they believed

suicide would allow their souls to leave the
human vessels and go on a spiritual journey

alongside the coment Hale-Bopp (pronounced:
hail-bop)

• Various male members went under voluntary
castration in preperation for their new genderless

existence aboard the comet, and while they
successfully committed suicide, one member

fell into a coma and waited most of a year
before completing it

• Tragically, actress Nichelle Nichols from
the original series of Star Trek - her brother

covered his head in a plastic bag and used
propane gas to end his own life, the suicide

note explaining he went the same way as the
rest of Heaven's Gate

10 - Teutonic Women,
• Another old story from 102 BC taking place

in France, where the king of the Teutones
was imprisoned and forced to make a deal with

the Romans
• He offered up three hundred married woman

to be handed over as sex slaves, to which
they begged instead to be allowed to minister

in the temples of Ceres and Venus instead
• After their plea was rejected, these women

slaughtered their own children and then strangled
each other during the night, effectively ending

the deal before it even had a chance to take
place

9 - The Solar Temple,
• It was 1994 when members of this cult

committed mass suicide, their intention to
escape the oppression and atrocities of the

modern world
• Some left a note indicating they'd be

travelling spiritually to the planetary system
of Sirius, the brightest star in the night

sky
• They left a number of suicide notes for

their family members and set their building
on fire, with the leader ordering the execution

of a newborn baby he referred to as his anti-christ
8 - Saipan,

• This was an act by the Japanese population
of Saipan when threatened with invading US

troops
• Believing they'd be tortured and murdered

due to internal propaganda, the citizens of
Saipan elected to walk off 250 meter cliffs

instead, where families would kill themselves
one-by-one

• Youngest children were pushed by the eldest
children, mothers pushed the eldest, fathers

pushed the mothers and jumped in after them
- a horrifying display, unfathomable today,

over 22,000 people dead
7 - Vietnam,

• This was less of a mass suicide and more
of a hardcore protest that spread - monks

that fearlessly lit themselves on fire
• It was in protest of the Vietnam war and

the continued persecution of Buddhists in
South Vietnam, with the famous example of

a monk in 1963 who did it in a crowded city
street

• Though the Buddhist community revered
his actions, the government felt the opposite

and punished them further, leading to more
and more self-immolation in order to spread

the light of the Dharma and spread the word
6 - MRTC,

• A catholic offshoot known as the Movement
for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments

of God, first seen in the 1980s after the
Virgin Mary reappeared to order us to obey

the 10 commandments
• Members were prohibited from engaging

in sex and forced to stop themselves from
eating every couple of weeks as judgement

day drew near
• When judgement day came and past, they

invented a new judgement day and all 1000
members were promised salvation - in the form

of self-immolation and poisoning
5 - 1945 Nazi Germany,

• In the final days of Hitler's regime when
Allied forces came bearing down on them, a

good chunk of Nazi's decided to take their
own lives than face the consequences of their

actions
• With the suicide of Adolf Hitler, coupled

with Nazi propoganda, many officers were overwhelmed
with the realisation of utter defeat, leading

to one of the biggest mass suicides ever
• Over 7000 suicides were reported in Berlin

alone with many, many more spread all over
Germany

4 - Branch Davidian Seventh-Day Adventists,
• A sect created in 1959 when once guy announced

the second coming of Jesus on a Texas hilltop,
which never happened

• But like with a lot of these cults, it
didn't even phase then - other prophets stepped

up and in 1994 the FBI turned up to investigate
rumours of firearm ownership and child abuse

• The branch wouldn't go down without a
fight - days passed, they barricaded themselves

in and the FBI attempted to subdue them with
tear gas, but they instead lit their own building

on fire and committed mass suicide
3 - Pilenai,

• This is a 1336 tale set in the castle
of Pilenai which, at the time, was besieged

by Teutonic Knights
• 4000 soldiers defended the castle walls,

but the Duke responsible realised they were
only delaying the inevitable - the knights

would crush both their army and their castle
• Instead of submitting to a life of slavery,

he called upon his troops to burn down the
castle and everyone in them, a final victory

that destroyed all their possessions and rendered
the knights attack meaningless

2 - Chittor,
• 1303 AD, the fort of Chittor is attacked

by the Delhi army, so the queen decides to
instead lead all the royal ladies, over 700

women alongside their children directly into
a bonfire

• They did this to protect themselves from
the torment of mass rape, while giving the

men a chance to lead a valiant suicide charge
against the enemy

• Since the men had no children or women,
their lives destroyed, they would not desert

this final charge, though the Delhi army was
clearly too powerful and all the men perished

valiantly
1 - Dance of Zalongo

• The name given due to an act by women
and children during the Souliote War of 1803

in current day Greece
• When 50 women and their children were

cornered by Souli troops in the mountains
of Zalongo, they hurled their children off

the cliff and then jumped after them to escape
